entry.title: Re: Monitor External Requirements ‚Äì ‚ÄúToo many data record...
entry.content:
Good day @Aght 

Thank you for your question.

To answer your first question, yes it is if your filter function does not cover the required fields.

The system seems to be working as designed. If you miss any critical selection parameter, the backend reads the full MRP dataset and triggers too many records and thereby returns no results. Which then shows no data.

First, I suggest you also filter the Requirement Evaluation Period to limit the search the system carries out. If something is available, the system should generate data.

Alternatively, it could also mean you have no external requirement open for the chosen plants and products. and therefore, no data is generated. I ran the test and the system also provided no data.

What I also did is to run a check on the Monitor Material Coverage APP. As you can see below, the system produced some data showing there are shortages. I suggest you check in this app using the same materials on your screenshot to evaluate if you have some shortages. If you did not find any, then the Alert.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Hide company code by default
entry.content:
Good day @TobiasVoigt 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Configuring Business Roles, Assigning Business Roles to a User, Best Practices for Business Roles, How to Create a Business Role from a Template, Restricting Access Roles, Manage Consolidation Hierarchies

To summarise, the public cloud provides the restriction request through business role restrictions and not through structural configuration. The simplest clean-core way to do what you are intending, is to create one dedicated role that explicitly allows this company code, while all other roles remain without access. Which then means, only users with this special role will see the company code in apps, analytics and value helps. This helps you avoid role duplication.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Copy Text from Sevrice Order to Billing Document
entry.content:
Good day @simon_all4cloud41 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud does not offer the possibility to transfer service order or service confirmation texts directly into the Billing Document text tabs. You can only do that for SD documents.

Considering the public cloud principle restricts some functionalities, you can only achieve your requirements without custom fields by including the text in the billing output PDF and enabling a service confirmation text through output parameter determination and then map it into the billing form.

However, if your business requirement is to store the text inside the Billing Document itself, you can achieve it only through custom field and custom logic.

Have a look at the following references.

Service Processing Using a Service Order, Service Order Processing,  Service Order - Confirm Processing, Billing Document, Output Determination in the Billing Document

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Event Driven SAP CAP on Kyma with Agentic AI and UI Auto Refresh
entry.content:
Introduction:
This prototype demonstrates how a simple CAP application can evolve into an event-driven architecture enriched with autonomous agentic AI. The objective was to show how CAP can react to external events in real time, refresh the UI automatically, and trigger an AI workflow that identifies duplicate citizens without any user action. The solution combines Kyma, SAP CAP, SAP HANA Cloud DB, SAP Integration Suite, a Python agent/Open AI, all running together.

Demo:

End-to-End Flow:
This application is built around a simple idea: when a citizen is created in the system, everything should react automatically.

The process starts in SAP Integration Suite. This is the continuation of the last Blog Post . The iFlow inserts the new citizen into HANA Cloud and then calls CAP‚Äôs notify endpoint with a simple JSON payload. This notify call is the explicit trigger, because CAP does not detect database changes on its own. Once CAP receives the notification, it broadcasts the event through its citizen stream endpoint using Server-Sent Events.

The UI and the Python agent are both listening to this stream. When they receive the event, each reacts independently. The UI refreshes its Fiori Elements binding and displays the new record. The agent retrieves the citizen through CAP OData, performs duplicate detection, prompts Open AI, and writes its suggestions back through CAP. CAP exposes the suggestions via virtual enrichment fields so that the UI automatically displays AI insights during the next read.

 

iFlow Changes:

Code:

GitHub: User - shahidla. Repository - citizen-master-cap-docker

Agentic AI:
The agent is packaged as a Python container running in Kyma. It listens continuously to the citizen stream. When it receives a CitizenCreated event it reads the citizen through OData, prompts Open AI with a structured tool-based instruction set and follows the returned JSON. Open AI selects the next actions such as fetching the citizen again, running a duplicate search or writing the final suggestion.

To make the AI transparent, a thinking log table records each step in the agent run including search inputs, candidate lists, scores and final reasoning. Users can view not only the AI result but also how the agent reached that conclusion. This makes the system trustworthy and audit friendly rather than a black box.

Execution results:

AI Agent Thinking Logs:

Conclusion:
This prototype shows that a CAP application can be extended into a fully event driven and agentic AI and can all run together inside Kyma without additional infrastructure The result is a responsive and intelligent application that reacts to new information immediately and explains every decision it makes.

Disclaimer:
This prototype intended for learning and demonstration. It is not production grade and does not include full durability. AI reasoning results should be validated and not used for decisions without proper governance. A real solution would require reviewing security, performance, and data privacy aspects. Terminology may have been used freely as part of experimentation.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model: What‚Äôs New as of 2025-12-01?
entry.content:
Greetings, SAP Community! 

The SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Universal Model continues to advance, and in this blogpost, I will outline the latest features and enhancements designed to further improve efficiency, transparency, and agility in business modeling and performance analysis. 

Model 

Manage Transfer Structure new type Reverse Transfer Structure 

Transfer Structure is a Function that helps reshaping or enriching your data based on the rules you set up. Think of each rule as a simple ‚Äúif this happens, then do that‚Äù instruction. The ‚Äúif‚Äù part tells SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model when a rule should apply‚Äîbasically which rows to look at. The ‚Äúthen‚Äù part tells SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model what to change in those rows, like filling in certain fields or replacing values. If the data doesn‚Äôt meet the conditions in your rule, SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model just leaves it alone and passes it through untouched.‚ÄØ 

The Transfer Structure function now has two (2) Types.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ  

‚ÄØ 

With the new Reverse Transfer Structure type, it takes data that is spread across multiple columns and transforms it into rows. This is often called ‚Äúunpivoting‚Äù the data. It‚Äôs helpful when you need to turn wide tables into a long, tidy format that‚Äôs easier to analyze or use in calculations.‚ÄØ 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model  Transfer Structure > Reverse Transfer Structure‚ÄØ  

Data Screen Improvements: Global Renaming and Visibility Control  

Previously, a feature in the Data screen was introduced wherein you can rename the field description. When you changed a field name, it changed only in Data screen specific layout where the renaming of field was done. Now with the ‚ÄúStore Globally in Environment‚Äù option enabled, any field change which includes renaming, is automatically applied across all layouts within the same environment.‚ÄØ 

If a field in the Data Screen is renamed with the ‚ÄúStore Globally in Environment‚Äù option checked in the Edit Column dialog (opened by choosing Edit (pencil) icon), the new name is applied globally in all layouts of the environment. Renaming of such fields will also be applied globally, and the following message will be displayed: ‚ÄúField was renamed globally. Next renaming also will be applied globally.‚Äù. 

Apart from the field renaming enhancements in Data Screen, another enhancement has been done in Data screen wherein if the Field has the Control Type Hidden in the function configuration (Model Entity), the field will not be displayed in any Data screen layouts (Standard and Customized). It will no longer available in the Columns panel or Reports Show Elements and will also be excluded from exports. It will ensure consistent behavior and alignment with hidden field logic across all layouts. 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model Data Screen 

Process 

Transport Support for Manage Data Locks, Manage Data Privilege and Manage Layouts  

A new feature has been implemented in which Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts created for AddOn environment are now transportable wherein these will be included upon environment export when marked for transport, even if they refer to a function owned by a protected environment. Once exported, they can be moved to the target tenant through environment import. This also applies to regular/unprotected environments as well.  

Important points to note: 

  • During environment export, Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts will be excluded if it refers to a function or activity function (e.g. activity within runtime environment but assigned activity function from another runtime environment) from a different environment. There will be a warning message that will be prompted upon export action and logged in Event Logs. 
  • During environment import, Data Privileges, Data Locks, and Layouts with inconsistent values (e.g. referring to a non-existing function or activity) will prompt an error message that a function or activity is missing in the target tenant.  
  • During AddOn environment import, the existence of the external function will be validated. If the function is not found in the target tenant, it will be removed from the corresponding Data Locks and Data Privileges. 

How does it work? 

For the following scenario, Tenant 01 will be the source tenant and Tenant 02 will be the target tenant. 

Source Tenant 01 - New field ‚ÄúTransport Data Privilege‚Äù checkbox is displayed in Data Privilege object page which can be marked as enabled and unmarked as disabled. This applies to Data Locks as well.  

Source Tenant 01 - Upon save of Data Privilege, it will show as ‚ÄúYes‚Äù when Transport Data Privilege checkbox is marked while it will show as ‚Äú-‚Äú when unmarked. This applies to Data Locks as well.  

When enabled, transportable Data Privileges and Data Locks will be included in the exported environment container.  

 

Target Tenant 02 - Upon environment import and activation, the transportable Data Privilege and Data Locks has been moved to the target tenant. 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model Manage Layouts, Manage Data Privileges, and Manage Data Locks 

Manage Process and Manage Activities: Updating Activity Run Status after Process reset  

 A new behavior has been implemented that the Run Status will be reset together with State of a dependent Activity. Run Status will change from its initial value after execution (which can be ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, ‚ÄúWarning‚Äù, or ‚ÄúError‚Äù) to its default value ‚ÄúNo Run‚Äù upon Process reset.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

The State of a dependent Activity will still have the same behavior wherein its initial value (which can be ‚ÄúActive‚Äù, ‚ÄúConfirmed‚Äù, or ‚ÄúRejected‚Äù) will be changed to its default value ‚ÄúInactive‚Äù once Process is reset. This behavior applies as well to Process and Activity elements in Report Screen.‚ÄØ 

The purpose of this change is to avoid misleading information when determining an Activity whether the task is completed or not.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ 

 Activity after Run is performed‚ÄØ 

‚ÄØ 

 Process resetting‚ÄØ 

Activity after Process reset is performed‚ÄØ 

For more information, please refer to Application Help for Universal Model  Manage Processes - Reset‚ÄØ 

Thank you for taking the time to read this update. 

We invite you to explore the newest enhancements in the SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model, and we encourage you to follow our ongoing ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New‚Äù series. For previous updates, feel free to browse the PaPMCloudUMWhatsNew tag.

entry.title: Re: How to populated the VAT registration number for Busi...
entry.content:
Hi Emal,

In ECC, the tax numbers are stored in Tax number 1, 2,3,4,5 and VAT registration field which are separate fields on screen of XK01 and in table KNA1. However In S4 HANA, we have 1 tab for Tax Numbers which you have highlighted. In expects a category and tax number. Category is nothing but a combination of "Country cod and N".  N is derived based on where the tax is stored in ECC. If customer is from Italy and tax is stored in Tax number 1 in ECC then N = 1 and tax category in S4 HANA is IT1. Similarly Tax number 2 has value then IT2, Tax number 3 = IT3, Tax Number4 = IT4, Tax Number 5 = IT5 and VAT in ECC is 0 meaning tax category will always be IT0.

So in your case it would be category 0 for VAT number.

Customer Tax category     Tax Number

12345        DE0                     DE0000***

Please reward if you find this answer helpful. Also confirm if this helps

entry.title: Mastering GitOps with Argo CD: A Complete Guide to Declarative Kubernetes Deployments
entry.content:
Introduction

In the world of cloud-native engineering, agility and reliability often clash. Developers need speed; operators need control. Traditional CI/CD pipelines, though effective, rely heavily on manual approvals, ad-hoc scripting, and push-based workflows ‚Äî all prone to configuration drift and human error.

GitOps changes the game by using Git as the single source of truth for both infrastructure and application configurations. With Argo CD, a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery controller, you can automate deployments, enforce configuration consistency, and self-heal your clusters ‚Äî all through declarative manifests stored in Git.

This article provides an end-to-end, production-ready walkthrough of how to design, deploy, and operate Kubernetes workloads using Argo CD and GitOps principles ‚Äî including advanced features such as multi-environment automation, Helm integration, sync policies, and best practices for scale.

What Is GitOps?

GitOps is a modern methodology for managing and operating cloud-native infrastructure and applications using Git as the single source of truth. It shifts the deployment paradigm from manual, imperative commands (like kubectl apply) to a declarative, automated workflow, where the desired state of your system is stored and versioned in Git.

Key principles of GitOps include:

1. Git as the Source of Truth

  • All infrastructure and application configurations are defined declaratively in Git.
  • Git commits represent the desired system state, enabling versioning, traceability, and auditability.

2. Pull-Based Automation

  • A GitOps operator continuously monitors Git for changes and reconciles the live system with the desired state.
  • Any drift between Git and the running environment is detected and corrected automatically.

3. Automated Rollbacks and Auditing

  • Since every change is a Git commit, rolling back to a previous state is as simple as reverting a commit.
  • All actions are auditable, providing a clear history of changes and deployments.

In essence: With GitOps, you declare what you want, commit it to Git, and let automation ensure that your cluster matches that desired state ‚Äî reliably, securely, and consistently.

It combines the benefits of version control, CI/CD, and automation into a single, streamlined approach for managing modern cloud-native applications.

Why Choose Argo CD?

Argo CD is a Kubernetes-native continuous delivery tool that fully implements GitOps principles, making it an ideal choice for teams seeking automation, reliability, and scalability. Here‚Äôs why Argo CD stands out:

1. Continuous Synchronization

  • Automatically monitors Git repositories and synchronizes changes to Kubernetes clusters.
  • Ensures the live state always matches the desired state defined in Git.

2. Real-Time Drift Detection and Self-Healing

  • Detects any manual changes or configuration drift in the cluster.
  • Automatically corrects deviations to maintain consistency.

3. Multi-Cluster and Multi-Environment Support

  • Manage deployments across multiple clusters and environments from a single Argo CD instance.
  • Supports environment overlays for dev, staging, and production setups.

4. Application Visualization and Health Monitoring

  • Provides a UI and CLI to visualize application status, dependencies, and health.
  • Supports monitoring health states like Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, or Suspended.

5. Support for Multiple Deployment Tools

  • Deploy raw YAML, Helm charts, Kustomize overlays, or Jsonnet configurations.
  • Flexible enough to handle simple apps or complex, multi-service systems.

6. Secure and Role-Based Access

  • Built-in RBAC for controlling access to applications, clusters, and repositories.
  • Ensures secure operations in collaborative, multi-team environments.

In short: Argo CD transforms Git commits into the live state of your Kubernetes clusters ‚Äî consistently, automatically, and safely ‚Äî making it a trusted GitOps engine for modern cloud-native deployments.

Step 1: Setting Up Argo CD

Let‚Äôs deploy Argo CD in a Kubernetes cluster.

Prerequisites

  • A Kubernetes cluster (Minikube, Kind, AKS, EKS, or GKE)
  • kubectl installed and configured
  • A GitHub or GitLab repository for your manifests

Installing Commands

kubectl create namespace argocd
kubectl apply -n argocd \
  -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/argoproj/argo-cd/stable/manifests/install.yaml

Once deployed, Argo CD runs several components:

  • argocd-server ‚Äì exposes the UI, API, and CLI
  • argocd-repo-server ‚Äì interacts with Git repositories
  • argocd-application-controller ‚Äì reconciles application states
  • argocd-dex-server ‚Äì handles authentication
  • argocd-redis ‚Äì caching and internal coordination

Accessing the UI

kubectl port-forward svc/argocd-server -n argocd 8080:443

Then open https://localhost:8080.

Retrieve the admin password:

kubectl -n argocd get secret argocd-initial-admin-secret \
  -o jsonpath="{.data.password}" | base64 -d

 

Step 2: Connecting a Git Repository

In the Argo CD UI:
Settings ‚Üí Repositories ‚Üí Connect Repo ‚Üí Add Git URL + Credentials.

Alternatively, via CLI:

argocd repo add https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git \
  --username <user> --password <token>

Argo CD now watches this repository and continuously scans it for configuration changes.

Step 3: Creating and Deploying Applications

Applications are the core Argo CD resources. They define what to deploy, where, and how.

Sample Application Definition

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
metadata:
  name: nginx-demo
  namespace: argocd
spec:
  project: default
  source:
    repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/gitops-manifests.git
    path: apps/nginx
    targetRevision: main
  destination:
    server: https://kubernetes.default.svc
    namespace: demo
  syncPolicy:
    automated:
      prune: true
      selfHeal: true
    syncOptions:
      - CreateNamespace=true

Apply this:

kubectl apply -f nginx-application.yaml

Argo CD fetches the manifests, applies them to the cluster, and keeps them in sync with Git automatically.

 

Step 4: Understanding Deployment Strategies

Argo CD supports multiple deployment approaches:

1. Plain YAML

Store raw manifests under version control ‚Äî simplest setup but less flexible.

2. Helm Charts

Argo CD can deploy Helm charts directly without helm CLI:

source:
  repoURL: https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami
  chart: nginx
  targetRevision: 13.2.9
  helm:
    values: |
      replicaCount: 3
      service:
        type: ClusterIP

3. Kustomize Overlays

Perfect for multi-environment management:

my-app/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ base/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ deployment.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ service.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ overlays/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dev/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ prod/
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ kustomization.yaml

4. App-of-Apps Pattern

Used to manage complex systems:

source:
  repoURL: https://github.com/myorg/environment-configs.git
  path: environments/dev

Step 5: Configuration and Synchronization

Sync Policies

Argo CD supports both manual and automated synchronization.

  • Manual Mode: Operators review and trigger syncs manually.
  • Automated Mode: Argo CD applies changes as soon as they are committed to Git.

Example:

syncPolicy:
  automated:
    prune: true
    selfHeal: true
  • Prune removes obsolete resources that no longer exist in Git.
  • SelfHeal ensures that any manual cluster change is automatically reverted.

Sync Options

Argo CD provides advanced sync behaviors:

syncOptions:
  - CreateNamespace=true
  - ApplyOutOfSyncOnly=true
  - PrunePropagationPolicy=foreground

Hooks and Lifecycle Management

You can use Argo CD Resource Hooks to run pre- and post-deployment tasks like database migrations or config validation.

Example:

metadata:
  annotations:
    argocd.argoproj.io/hook: PreSync

Step 6: Observability and Health Monitoring

Argo CD continuously monitors application health using Kubernetes object statuses.

  • Health states: Healthy, Progressing, Degraded, Suspended
  • You can visualize these in the Argo CD UI tree view.

For deeper insights:

  • Metrics: Argo CD exposes Prometheus metrics at /metrics.
  • Dashboards: Integrate with Grafana to visualize sync frequency, drift count, and app health.
  • Notifications: Use Argo CD Notifications for Slack, Teams, or email alerts.

Example config:

triggers:
  - name: on-sync-failure
    condition: app.status.sync.status == 'OutOfSync'
    template: sync-failure

Step 7: Real-World Deployment Workflow

Here‚Äôs a simplified GitOps deployment lifecycle using Argo CD:

  1. Developer updates the manifest or Helm values ‚Üí commits to Git.
  2. CI validates YAML syntax and performs static checks.
  3. Commit is merged to the main branch.
  4. Argo CD detects the commit, fetches the new configuration, and starts reconciliation.
  5. Application is deployed to the cluster.
  6. If any manual drift occurs, Argo CD flags ‚ÄúOutOfSync‚Äù and reverts automatically.
  7. Rollback is as easy as git revert <commit-hash>.

This process guarantees full traceability, automatic rollback, and no manual cluster changes.

Summary: Argo CD as the GitOps Engine

Argo CD brings automation, reliability, and control to Kubernetes deployments through GitOps. It replaces manual, error-prone processes with a declarative, Git-driven model where every change is versioned, traceable, and automatically synchronized to clusters. As environments scale across microservices and multiple clusters, Argo CD ensures consistency, eliminates drift, and enables faster, safer releases. Ultimately, it transforms Git into the operational control plane and provides a predictable, self-healing, and highly observable deployment workflow ‚Äî allowing teams to move quickly without compromising stability.

You define your desired state once, commit to Git, and Argo CD ensures your clusters reflect it ‚Äî continuously and automatically.

This declarative model brings:

  • Auditability: every change is a commit
  • Reliability: drift is self-corrected
  • Scalability: consistent rollout across clusters
  • Security: code-based governance over live clusters

Conclusion

Argo CD is more than a deployment tool ‚Äî it is the operational engine that modernizes how organizations manage Kubernetes at scale. By embracing GitOps, teams shift from fragile, manual, push-based deployments to a fully automated, audit-ready, and self-healing delivery model. Every environment becomes predictable, every rollout becomes traceable, and every configuration becomes reproducible.

As applications grow into distributed microservices and clusters expand across regions or clouds, Argo CD provides the consistency and governance required to keep everything in sync. Its declarative, pull-based architecture eliminates configuration drift, while features like automated sync, app-of-apps orchestration, Helm/Kustomize support, and environment overlays allow teams to design enterprise-grade delivery pipelines with confidence.

In essence, Argo CD turns Git into a control plane for your entire Kubernetes footprint. It bridges the gap between developers and operators by delivering a unified, reliable, and observable deployment workflow.

Adopting GitOps with Argo CD is not just a tooling decision ‚Äî it is an engineering culture upgrade. It empowers teams to deploy faster, recover instantly, collaborate better, and operate with clarity at every stage of the software lifecycle.

In a world where speed and stability are equally critical, Argo CD ensures you never have to choose between the two.

entry.title: How many industries, countries/regions, and languages ‚Äã‚Äãdoes SAP S/4HANA Cloud support?

entry.title: Re: The destination set for ur participant ID does not ma...
entry.content:
Root cause:

  • The participant ID you are using as the sender in eCockpit is linked to a destination that does not correspond to the system from which you are submitting the document.
  • This often happens when:
    • The destination in SAP BTP is incorrectly configured.
    • The participant ID mapping in the Master Data Management app or Peppol Exchange Service is missing or incorrect.
    • The wrong system alias or destination name is assigned in the eDocument Cockpit configuration

Solution

The destination set for your participant ID does not match the system you are trying to submit the electronic document from‚Äù in SAP eDocument Cockpit (eCockpit) usually occurs due to a mismatch between the participant ID configuration and the destination system settings in SAP BTP.

1. Verify Participant ID Setup

  • Go to SAP Document and Reporting Compliance ‚Üí Master Data Management App.
  • Check that the participant ID is registered and linked to the correct system.
  • If using Peppol or similar network, ensure the participant ID is active for sending (and optionally receiving) documents

2. Check Destination in SAP BTP Cockpit

  • Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit.
  • Navigate to Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations.
  • Confirm:
    • The destination name matches what is configured in eCockpit.
    • The URL/host points to the correct system (S/4HANA or middleware).
    • Authentication settings are correct.
  • If needed, edit and save the destination

3. Validate Additional Parameters

  • In the destination configuration, check Additional Properties:
    • sap-client (client number)
    • systemAlias or similar identifiers
  • These must match the system you are submitting from.

4. Update eCockpit Settings

  • In EDOC_COCKPIT or Manage Electronic Documents (Fiori):
    • Ensure the communication arrangement (e.g., SAP_COM_0521) is linked to the correct destination.
    • If using Integration Suite, verify the outbound service destination is correct.

5. Clear and Retry

  • After correcting configuration:
    • Clear the error in eCockpit.
    • Resubmit the document

entry.title: Re: how to upgrade SAP BTP trial account to free tier acc...
entry.content:
Hi jerlin_d,

as far as I know an upgrade from your personal trial account to an enterprise free tier account is not possible.

Please open https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-ai-core and log in with your SAP user (version: For SAP developer should be displayed) to get info how you as SAP user get provisioned SAP AI Core into an account.

Hope that helps. Best regards, Jens

entry.title: Re: how to upgrade SAP BTP trial account to free tier acc...
entry.content:
Hi jerlin_d,

Furthermore, I want to emphasize that 'Free Tier' is not an account type, but a "set of free services that can be used within an enterprise account", for details see below reference [1].
There you and all customers could also find how to get an enterprise BTP account, where 'Free Tier', set set of free services, can be use.

Your personal free trial is not an enterprise account, and even though you can use there many BTP Services for free, not all of the 'Free Tier' is currently offered in personal trial accounts, like SAP AI Core.

Hope that helps.
Best regards, Jens

[1] https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/getting-global-account?version=Cloud

5) ÂØπ‰∫éËØ• App È°µÈù¢ÁöÑ‰øÆÊîπÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÁÇπÂáªÂè≥‰∏äËßíÁöÑÁ£ÅÁõòÂõæÊ†áËøõË°å‰øùÂ≠ò„ÄÇËã•ÊÇ®Á°ÆËÆ§Â∑≤ÂÆåÊàêË∞ÉÊï¥ÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÁÇπÂáªÂ∑¶‰∏äËßíÁöÑÊøÄÊ¥ªÊåâÈíÆÔºåËæìÂÖ•‰∏Ä‰∏™Â¢ûÂº∫ÁâàÊú¨ËØ¥ÊòéÂêéÔºåÁÇπÂáª‚ÄúConfirm / Á°ÆËÆ§ / Á¢∫Ë™ç‚Äù„ÄÇÊúÄÂêéÁÇπÂáªÂ∑¶‰∏äËßíÁöÑÂèëÂ∏ÉÊåâÈíÆÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞ÜÂºÄÂßãÂú®ÂêéÂè∞‰∏∫ÊÇ®ÂèëÂ∏ÉËøô‰∏ÄÂèòÊõ¥Ôºå‰ΩøÂΩìÂâçÁ≥ªÁªüÁéØÂ¢É‰∏ãÊâÄÊúâÁî®Êà∑ÂùáÂèØÁúãÂà∞Ëøô‰∏ÄÂèòÊõ¥„ÄÇ

entry.title: Re: Destinations Not Available in Automations
entry.content:
Make sure:

  1. The destination is also created in your BTP subaccount (not only in SAP Build Control Tower):

    • Go to BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount ‚Üí Connectivity ‚Üí Destinations.

    • Confirm an equivalent destination exists there with:

       *Type = HTTP or Type = OAuth2... (supported types),

      • Proxy Type typically Internet or OnPremise as needed,

      • Authentication is one of the supported ones.

  2. In Control Tower ‚Üí Destinations you might have created a ‚ÄúBuild-only‚Äù destination which:

    • Is visible to Action Projects,

    • But not automatically to Automations.

If it exists only in Control Tower and not in BTP, add it also in BTP.

 

  • Check which subaccount / region your Automation project belongs to.

  • Check if the destination in the BTP cockpit exists in that same subaccount.

entry.title: Non‚ÄëPO Invoices: When to Use Them and When Not
entry.content:
Invoices submitted without a reference to a purchase order or a contract are common in many organizations. For their lack of reference, they are referred as non-PO Invoices in the invoice processing systems across the AP scope.

Non‚ÄëPO invoices solve real problems but also introduce risks. In this short guide I'm trying to explain how often they are used, when they make sense, what risks they represent, and practical actions to be taken by procurement leaders.

How much they‚Äôre used

Typical usage of non-PO invoices by organizations lies in 5‚Äì30% interval of invoice volume and 5‚Äì25% of AP spend. This can differ per industry segments, but higher ratios exceeding 30% may be indicators of slow PO processes, high services spend, many small vendors, or immature procurement systems. For organizations it points to opportunities for improvements in their efficiency and compliance targets.

When non‚ÄëPO invoices make sense

There are cases, where non-PO invoices are unavoidable and include number of scenarios that can be handled without loosing control:

  • Emergency or safety‚Äëcritical purchases where creating a PO would cause unwanted delays
  • Professional services billed on milestones, time & materials, or when scope/price is agreed after work begins
    (unless they are covered by contracts to which the invoices could be referring to)
  • Suppliers that cannot accept POs (small/legacy suppliers in challenging regions)
  • Very low‚Äëvalue transactions where PO overhead exceeds benefit
  • Highly exceptional cases, when PO cannot be created, e.g. system outages, transitions, etc.

When non‚ÄëPO invoices are NOT a good practice

Sometimes organizations keep their "long term" legacy practices, because "it is so comfortable to do it our time-proven way". Many opportunities can be missed, more manual effort in the invoice matching activities is required, and organizations tend to run in circles, unable to unlock the trap.

Try to avoid the following (or similar) areas, where non-PO invoices are part of the picture:  

  • Repeat purchases from the same supplier that should be on contract or catalog
  • High‚Äëvalue or strategic spend where PO terms protect pricing, delivery and liability
  • Categories with clear opportunities for consolidation or volume discounts
  • Environments with known fraud or duplicate payment risk and weak AP controls

When there is an overlay between the existing structured buying channels (catalog/contract spend), or guarding commercial terms (payment/delivery/liability), non-PO invoices can be easily replaced. This will deliver efficiency improvements. 

Pros and cons

Decision makers in the procurement organizations might be aware of the positive and negative aspects of the non-PO invoice practice in their purchasing processes. Here is the overview:

  •  Pros
    • Speed and flexibility for urgent or complex purchases
    • Preserves supplier relationships when suppliers won‚Äôt accept POs
    • Simpler for T&M or milestone invoicing for services (if tools for contract compliance/services spend are unavailable)
  • Cons
    • Higher maverick spend, weak spend control
    • Low visibility into budget, contracts and supplier performance
    • Higher AP processing costs and more invoice exceptions
    • Increased risk of fraud or duplicate payments
    • Slower month‚Äëend reconciliation and weaker sourcing discipline

Practical policy decisions and actions

  1. Define acceptable exceptions
    • Publish a short list of allowed cases (emergency, validated supplier, low‚Äëvalue threshold, services)
    • require a business justification field on every non‚ÄëPO invoice

  2. Set clear thresholds & approval matrix
    • Use amount thresholds tied to approval levels
      (e.g., Dept Manager for <500; Directorfor<5k; Procurement+Finance for larger amounts)
  3. Automate non‚ÄëPO workflows
    • Force mandatory fields (exception reason, GL code, cost center)
    • Route approvals automatically, and capture justification in the AR/AP system

  4. Monitor & report monthly
    • Track count and value of non‚ÄëPO invoices, repeat suppliers, time‚Äëto‚Äëapproval, and % of total AP spend
    • Create alerts for repeat non‚ÄëPO suppliers

  5. Convert repeat non‚ÄëPO spend
    • Onboard frequent non‚ÄëPO suppliers to catalogs, negotiated contracts or a managed marketplace (SpotBuy) within 60‚Äì90 days

  6. Strengthen supplier onboarding
    • Ensure vendors used for non‚ÄëPO invoices have basic validations (tax forms, bank details, insurance) before payments over a threshold

  7. Balance convenience with control
    • Offer low‚Äëfriction PO alternatives (catalogs, SpotBuy, pre‚Äëapproved templates) to reduce the need of non‚ÄëPO invoices

  8. Audit & continuous improvement
    • Periodically audit samples of non‚ÄëPO invoices for compliance, fraud indicators and opportunities to source differently

Quick target benchmarks 

How do you know, where you stand and whether you are successful in achieving your targets? You might want to use this simple guide of measurable process metrics to help you gain visibility of the non-PO invoicing process:

  • Healthy: non‚ÄëPO invoice volume <15% and non‚ÄëPO spend <10% of AP
  • Risky: non‚ÄëPO invoice volume 15‚Äì30% or non‚ÄëPO spend 10‚Äì25% ‚Äî implement remediation plan
  • Alarm: non‚ÄëPO invoice volume >30% or non‚ÄëPO spend >25% ‚Äî immediate controls, audit, and supplier enablement required

 

Final takeaway

Non‚ÄëPO invoices should be a controlled exception, not the norm. Make sure to limit their use with a clear policy, automate approvals and data capture, track them closely, and convert recurring non‚ÄëPO purchases into PO‚Äëbased channels where better savings, visibility and control can be delivered.

entry.title: Re: Datasphere SQL: expected_unsigned_integer error on ti...
entry.content:
Perhaps you could create your own function to output a given value at a the length detemined by the parameter?

Copilot came up with this:

CREATE FUNCTION TruncateString (
    input NVARCHAR(5000),
    length INT
)
RETURNS NVARCHAR(5000)
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE result NVARCHAR(5000);

    -- If input is NULL, return NULL
    IF :input IS NULL THEN
        result := NULL;
    ELSE
        -- If length is less than 1, return empty string
        IF :length <= 0 THEN
            result := '';
        ELSE
            -- Use SUBSTRING to truncate
            result := SUBSTRING(:input, 1, :length);
        END IF;
    END IF;

    RETURN :result;
END;

entry.title: Where Is My Stuff? ‚Äî Joule‚Äôs First Industry Release Brings AI-Driven Insight to Oil and Gas Upstream
entry.content:
The oil and gas domain has historically been one of the most stable but also conservative areas of enterprise architecture. Over multiple decades, SAP customers have evolved from custom ABAP solutions to standardized S/4HANA objects, Fiori applications, and integrated complex logistics planning and processes. While this has driven consistency and transactional efficiency, the core decision-making mechanisms in field logistics remained predominantly human-driven with, manual validation, and the experience of field and personnel.

SAP Field Logistics is a solution built on SAP S/4HANA. It is available on both S/4HANA private cloud and public cloud.  This solution enables customers leverage best in class industry practices to manage the logistics movement of their own- and third-party items between their supply and demand plants. 

We are happy to announce that in May 2025, we at SAP introduced a landmark innovation:

the very first Joule-enabled capability across all industries, delivered specifically within SAP Upstream Field Logistics.

This early release is subtle in scope but monumental in strategic significance. It marks the beginning of Field Logistics evolution from traditional business processes to a future where core FL operations become deeply AI-driven through Joule.

A Strategic First Step: Joule‚Äôs Inventory Insights for FL

The initial capability released in May focuses on a read-only non-stock inventory scenario, allowing users to retrieve consolidated product and equipment visibility through natural language and gives the latest milestone of its lifecycle to help to know where the equipment is located. Even though this first use case is intentionally controlled, it is designed as the foundation for a multi-release future where Joule will perform full field logistics (FL) transactions end-to-end.

SAP‚Äôs intention is clear:

Start small, prove value, ensure reliability, and then scale AI-driven operations across the entire upstream lifecycle.

This first release demonstrates Joule‚Äôs ability to:

  • Understand Field Logistics terminology in 50 different languages
  • Interpret users queries through Natural Language Processing and provide contextual answers instantly
  • Display list of products along with relevant information‚Äôs like plant, Purchase order, different quantities etc
  • Navigate to Manage logistics application from Joule to get a wholistic view

While simple on the surface, the underlying architecture sets the stage for powerful, future-ready logistics automation.

What This Means for Customers

 Faster, simpler access to operational intelligence

Users can ask Joule questions in natural language ‚Äî no need to navigate complex screens or interpret multiple reports.

Immediate visibility where it matters most

Inventory and material readiness have direct impact on non-productive time.

A future-proof foundation for autonomous logistics

This first release is intentionally scoped ‚Äî but designed for expansion into item receival, returns process, and more.

A clear step toward an ‚ÄúAI co-pilot‚Äù for upstream operations

Joule is not just a search tool. It is the beginning of a more intelligent, proactive, and predictive logistics environment.

Technical Highlights Behind the Scenes

While the customer experience focuses on simplicity, the technical implementation is sophisticated:

Flow Diagram

1. Semantic Understanding of FL and S/4HANA Operational Objects

Joule interprets upstream-specific structures such as:

  • Field Logistics items
  • PO, GR, Open and Return quantity
  • Latest Milestone
  • Non-stock Inventory availability data

This domain-awareness is what enables Joule to deliver precise, contextual answers.

2. Natural Language ‚Üí CDS Query Generation

Joule automatically translates plain language into data retrieval operations using:

  • CDS consumption views
  • FL OData APIs

This eliminates the need for custom queries or separate analytical tool.

Functionality:

Do follow the below link to understand about Joule and how to access the same in a Private Cloud system.

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/joule-for-sap-s-4hana-cloud-private-edition-a-comprehensive-setup-guide/ba-p/13786453

Once you login to your Fiori system as a Supply Chain Analyst persona and click on the Joule icon at the top, all the capabilities that are part of your user role will be available. Users also can click on helpful conversation starters instead of asking a question.

Certain mandatory parameters are needed to process the user utterance, for our capability the item number/ description must be provided. Additionally, optional parameters like plant could also be provided to narrow down the search results.

Joule displays a list of items that are relevant for your search along with some important fields such as PO and item, Latest Milestone.

You can click on each entry which would take you to a detail view wherein additional fields such as Order and various quantities can be viewed.

Also, there is a button at the bottom which can be used to Navigate to Manage Logistics application that filters the data already entered by the user.

 

Customer-Focused Future Roadmap

SAP has already signalled a multi-release roadmap to expand Joule‚Äôs Oil and Gas capabilities beyond visibility into actionable intelligence and automated logistics execution.

The Future Vision

This progression reflects SAP‚Äôs commitment to controlled, safe, value-driven rollout of Joule capabilities to field logistics operations.

Conclusion: A Small Release with a Massive Strategic Horizon

The May 2025 Joule capability for FL may be limited to inventory visibility, but it represents:

  • The first-ever Joule release across industries
  • The foundation of AI-enriched S/4HANA FL operations
  • The beginning of SAP‚Äôs broader AI transformation across line-of-business functions

Customers leveraging this early capability are not just gaining a new feature‚Äîthey are positioning themselves at the frontline of an industry-wide shift, where SAP systems evolve from transactional engines to intelligent co-pilots for complex field logistics operations.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA cloud public data migration practice test
entry.content:
Hello @Sakirat_Balogun 

Bawo ni.

Thank you for your question.

We appreciate your patience for the difficulties you are facing.

1. I cannot fully see if your file is correct but based on the details you provided, I can see you might have saved an Excel sheet renamed as .xml, not a real XML file. Which causes the Migration Cockpit to reject it every time.

I suggest you re-download the template and make sure you choose XML Spreadsheet 2003 format (.xml). Then fill the rows and make sure you save directly from Excel in the same XML format. (File √† Save As √† Browse: XML Spreadsheet 2003(*.xml). Then try uploading again.

The reason the system produces the error that your file has one line, might be due to the fact the file was renamed from XLSX to XML. Excel compresses all content into one line if this is done. Therefore, the Migration Cockpit reads it as invalid.

2. Manage Your Test Process is not missing because of Exercise 9. The Test Automation Tool is not available in Practice Tenant; it only exists in the Quality or Productive tenant system. Which is why you cannot complete 11-13.

In summary, complete your exercise 9 by making sure your XML is correct. You can still register for your exam even if you do not complete 11-13.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: RAP navigation to object page of another app as a lin...
entry.content:
Hello @Shweta3005 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Intent-Based Navigation, Deep Links to Apps, Deep Linking in Monitor Workflows App     

In summary, due to the clean-core principle in public cloud, the system does not permit you to create a header link in the Object Page by using CDS annotations. Simply saying, the public cloud does not allow modification of CDS UI annotations.

However, you can achieve that when you use UI Adaptation and then add a custom navigation link through Semantic Object. The Object page will open directly if your target app supports deep linking.

You may also find this source interesting: SAP Fiori Elements Tutorials, Courses, and Blogs

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Simplify Deployment and Monitoring with the CAP Console
entry.content:
As a developer, you've likely experienced the frustration of hunting through log files or wrestling with complex deployment procedures when you'd rather be focusing on writing code. The new CAP Console addresses these pain points.  Built by developers for developers, this tool evolved from the Developer Dashboard for Java. It simplifies both deployment and monitoring of your SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) applications on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), whether you‚Äôre working in Java or JavaScript.

This blog post will walk you through the key features of the CAP console, explaining how it streamlines deployment and monitoring, and why it‚Äôs a valuable addition to your development toolkit.

 

Getting Started with CAP Console

Setting up the CAP Console is straightforward. After downloading and installing it from SAP Tools, the console automatically scans your local processes to identify running CAP projects. Both JavaScript and Java projects are detected and listed on the start page, giving you immediate access to your active development work.

The console includes a "Remember Project" feature for projects you want to keep visible even when they're not running. You can also manually add projects, which is particularly useful for projects that aren't currently running or weren't detected automatically.

A filter option allows you to customize your project view, letting you filter by process status (running or stopped) and save status (detected or saved). This helps keep your workspace organized, especially when working with multiple projects simultaneously.

To utilize the full functionality of the CAP console, you need to install the CAP console plugin in your CAP project. The plugin is available for JavaScript and Java. Find detailed information how to install the CAP console plugin here.

 

Guided Deployment

Deployment is often a complex part of the development lifecycle, but the CAP Console makes it straightforward by offering step-by-step guidance. Starting a deployment is as simple as clicking "Add Deployment" for your chosen project. From there, the tool guides you through each step of the deployment procedure.

The process begins with the SAP BTP authentication, followed by SAP BTP account selection. The console presents a list of global accounts and subaccounts you can access, making it easy to choose your deployment target. If SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment isn't enabled in your selected subaccount, the tool helps you to enable it.

As a next step you have to select the Cloud Foundry space, where you want to deploy to. If this space is not existing, the tool creates it for you.

The wizard also reads your mta.yaml definition to identify required services and automatically checks resource availability in your accounts. In case of missing resources, you simply click ‚ÄúAssign Quota‚Äù and all necessary entitlements are added. In case an HDI container is defined in your mta.yaml file, the tool also checks whether the required SAP HANA Cloud instance exists. If it does not, the missing  service instance can be created.

You have two deployment options:

  • Deploy within the CAP Console: This option eliminates the need for CLI tool installations. Click "Deploy in CAP Console" and watch the deployment progress with real-time log information. The logs are automatically saved for later analysis.
  • Terminal Deployment: For developers, who prefer command-line control, the console provides automated Cloud Foundry CLI authentication and convenient copy buttons for copying deployment commands. You can paste these directly into your terminal without manual setup.

The console also supports default deployment target configuration, allowing you to set preferred global accounts, subaccounts, and spaces in your SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment that apply across all projects. These defaults can be overridden as needed during the deployment process.

 

Monitoring Made Simple

Once your application is deployed and you're logged into the Cloud Foundry environment, the monitoring view provides a graphical overview of your project‚Äôs structure and services based on your MTA configuration. Each component displays its current state through colored status indicators, along with real-time performance metrics including CPU and memory usage. Click any component to access detailed information about it, along with metadata like creation dates and direct links to the SAP BTP cockpit.

The interface includes practical controls for application management (start, stop, or restart your Cloud Foundry applications) without leaving the console. Where possible, you'll find direct links to corresponding sections in the SAP BTP cockpit. The console also provides information on the SAP BTP services defined in your project, such as the XSUAA service.

The integrated log viewer offers access to real-time logs with the ability to adjust log levels on the fly when using the CAP Console plugin. For Non-CAP applications and CAP applications without the plugin, Cloud Foundry logs are displayed instead. The log viewer includes convenient level switching ‚Äì simply select your desired level and view filtered logs without requiring restarts or additional configuration.

 

Easy Environment Switching

Most projects involve multiple environments like development, testing, production. The CAP console makes it easy to switch between them. This even includes your local development environment, though some features (like SAP BTP services) aren't available locally.

Environment configurations are git-friendly. They are stored in YAML files within the `.cds` folder, making them easy to share with your team. To remove an environment, simply delete its YAML file from the `.cds` folder.

Since the CAP Console doesn't store credentials, only team members with appropriate access to a space in the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment can connect to configured environments, maintaining security without additional credential management overhead

Even if the CAP console plugin isn‚Äôt installed in a particular environment, you can still connect - though with limited features (such as viewing logs or accessing the UI).

 

Security Considerations

The CAP Console prioritizes security through the following mechanisms:

Rather than managing separate credentials, it leverages your existing SAP BTP and SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment permissions. This means you can only access resources you already have permission to use.

For deployed environments, the console establishes a secure SSH tunnel to the application. This is used to communicate via a WebSocket connection with the CAP console plugin for Java or JavaScript running in your application. The console minimizes risk by automatically closing tunnels when connections end or access is revoked.

On Apple macOS, encrypted credential storage using the OS keychain provides convenient access without repeated logins. This functionality can be disabled in settings if preferred, and it's not available on Microsoft Windows due to platform limitations.

 

Ready to Get Started?

The CAP Console is available for download from SAP Tools. Read the documentation and give it a try and see how much smoother your CAP development workflow can be! If you have any questions or want to share your experience with the CAP console, feel free to leave a comment.

Happy coding!

entry.title: Re: Unable to create contact in Fiori App Manage Customer...
entry.content:
@riteshinamdar : Sorry for delay but this is how we resolve our issue.

Solution was provided by SAP.

There were inconsistencies between tables.

Business Partner "XXXXX" has the value ‚ÄòYYYY' in the IND_SECTOR field in table BUTO00, but tis value is absent in table TB038A.

Further investigation revealed that this IND_SECTOR mismatch affects all Business Partners with Industry ‚ÄòZZZZ'.

entry.title: Credit Approval issues in SAP-ECC
entry.content:
we have a couple issues related to the credit approval process in SAP.

  1. Multiple Customer credit approvals are required for an order.  ‚Äì ie, when a customer delivery date is changed a new credit approval request is generated.  This occurs even if the $ value of the order has not changed. Multiple credit approvals on an order should only be required if the value of the order has changed as approval has already been granted.

entry.title: Re: SAP HANA PARAMETERS TUNING FOR PERFORMANCE OPTIMIZATION
entry.content:
Hello @Ashutosh_Pandey1 ,

thanks for this comprehensive collection and sharing this information. The topic is such complex (hyperscaler, hypervisor, OS, application release dependencies) that you can fill books - believe me because we did it. 

But allow me some remarks:

  • do not recommend any OS parameters as they change over time (e.g. THP from never to madivse)
  • changing the I/O scheduler are highly depending on the used components (e.g. for flash and NVMe system you should use "none" for RHEL systems / details)
  • you are not referring or mentioning tools like tuned profiles / saptune which are really helpful and supported by the OS vendors
  • do not recommend outdated software like HANA Studio
  • smart merges are something totally different compared to your description, please correct it or reframe it
  • is network no KPI in your opinion? keep in mind that there are also scale-out and HSR systems out there! The overhead between server client can also be important

Keep always in mind that your recommendation may adapted by others. Only recommend something for a specific scenario or within a versioning.

The are many good documentation out there via SAP notes (3311408) or other tools like saphana-checks (https://github.com/SAP/arp142-hana). Try to link them, because they are updated frequently. You can also mention other great articles which already present and cover similar topics like from @Laszlo_Thoma (Collected information belongs to the topics of query execution and optimization in SAP HANA database )

Keep up posting but don't use content which is dynamic and can be outdated one day later. Describe more the methodology and the useful notes and documentation with some examples.

Regards,

Jens

entry.title: Theming the Icon Control with the UI ThemeDesigner
entry.content:
Introduction

With the latest version of the UI Theme Designer (‚Ä¶), a brand-new Icon Preview page has been introduced, making it easier than ever to theme icon controls.
The Icon control is a fundamental UI element in SAPUI5 applications: it displays small, meaningful symbols that help users navigate the interface, understand actions, and identify the purpose of buttons, statuses, and interactive elements at a glance. Whether it‚Äôs a simple navigation arrow, a status indicator, or an action button icon, consistent theming ensures that these visual cues integrate smoothly with the overall application design.

The new preview page allows designers and developers to efficiently adjust and preview icon colors, states, and visual behaviors ‚Äî all within a single, streamlined environment.

Theming the Icon Control

To theme the Icon control, start by opening your custom theme in the UI Theme Designer. Once the theme is loaded, add the new Icon Preview page to your preview section. Navigate to SAPUI5 Control Previews and simply activate the checkbox ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù.

 

Select the checkbox ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù to add your preview page

After opening the preview, you‚Äôll get an overview of a wide range of icons ‚Äî neatly categorized by color, state, and type.
This makes it easy to understand how each icon behaves within different UI scenarios.

If you want to adjust the styling, switch to Expert Mode. Click on the tag icon and select the ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù tag.

 

Once selected, the theming parameters relevant for icons appear.

 

Inside the expert mode select the tag ‚ÄúIcon‚Äù to display all related parameters

The most important parameters for customizing icon appearance are:

  • sapContent_IconColor ‚Äì the default color of icons
  • sapContent_ContrastIconColor ‚Äì the alternative icon color used for improved contrast
  • sapContent_NonInteractiveIconColor ‚Äì the color used for non-interactive icons

With these parameters, you can now fine-tune the icon styling directly within the UI Theme Designer‚Äôs Expert Mode.
This gives you full control to match your icons perfectly to your application's look and feel.

What do you think?

How do you like the new theming options for icons?
Share your thoughts with us in the comments ‚Äî we‚Äôre looking forward to your feedback!

entry.title: Re: Bank statement parse error in SAP B1
entry.content: Hi , it would be good to know what is the exact error: The electronic file format can provide meaningful errors when the error pertains to any of the defined validations in the Electronic File Format, in the case of a BFP type, the validations are set in the specific nodes in the validation tab. You can get as well some information when the problem is in some specific information of the Target, because the target in BFP is an xml representing the internal structure of the bank statement in B1, so you may get errors that are typical of schema syntax. Other type of errors, as could be your case, could be more obscure as may affect for example to the Encoding of the characters on the file, or some problem in the syntax of functions defined in the Electronic Format. The best way to approach the cases is by doing advanced test using the Add-on Electronic File Manager. The process on how to do this test is described in KBA 3351973 - SAP Business One Guided Answer: SAP Business One - Electronic File/Document/Report Failed to be Added or Generated. Have a look at it.

entry.title: Re: Repair order planned costs double upon release status
entry.content:
Good day @rcirujano_us 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Creating a Repair Order with a Service Product, Repair Order, Processing Planned Cost and Revenue, Calculation of Planned Cost and Revenue


Due to the public cloud‚Äôs clean-core approach, the doubling occurs when releasing a repair order item because the system recalculates you ongoing Planned Costs while also keeping your Baseline Planned Cost that was earlier created. If you have same values in both versions, the UI appears to show double costs, although the system does not post any duplication in CO/FI. 

I suggest you updated the baseline after release. Doing that will enable you avoid early baseline creation. Or you can consider hiding the baseline section through UI adaptation. See the links provided for further instructions.

To summarise, here is what you can do to eliminate the current state in your system:

  • Only make use of ongoing planned costs. Do not create a baseline until you finalise your planning.
  • You can recalculate your baseline by updating baseline and ensuring values align. It will eliminate doubling effect you are currently experiencing.
  • If you do not require you Baseline section for your business, use the UI adaption to block it.
  • Finally, check your system and ensure that you are not running any custom logic that is enhancing your cost calculation.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris
